The Big Demo: Enterprise-Hardy Stackato POC
On the Road with PaaS

2013 is The Year of the PaaS. Everyone at ActiveState knows this, but the industry at large is mostly in ignorance of the PaaS wave that’s on its way.

The opportunity is mind-boggling, but the challenges are equally huge. We need to get the message out to a largely-uneducated market now so we then ride this wave, front and center all the way to prosperous shores.

This challenges are enormous given the complexity of the product, the sheer breadth of its scope, and the immaturity of the market.

A technical demo / POC can be highly effective and appealing if it showcases the (astonishingly large) intersection of common enterprise software requirements and major Stackato features.

Current Stackato Demo Impact

Our current demo portfolio and app store inventory are compelling but are mostly directed at either programmers or IT.

As such we are missing the mark on several crucial areas of focus for enterprise software organizations and their decision makers. Like IT, these folks are keenly interested in high availability, scalability, security, and disaster recovery, but they’re more focused on the application and software development lifecycle perspective. These are areas that we barely touch on, except in reference to IaaS.

A strong demo suite that hits these areas hard, from a software development/engineering perspective, would fill this gap.

In short, we need an enterprise demo with teeth, one that’s aimed directly at corporate CTOs, CIOs, and Engineering VPs, but that also resonates strongly with architects and senior engineers.

The Teeth

Scaling is a hotspot. A scaling-centric POC, based on a minimalistic app with real-world requirements, will illustrate:

  • a coherent, planned, measurable, achievable scaling strategy

  • auto-scaling: what it means, on what configurations is it supported, how is it realized, what are its limitations

  • Stackato’s features and design that enable app scaling

  • leveraging logging to scale

  • bundled performance measurement and instrumentation

  • bundled Scaling Best Practices

Takehome: With Stackato, scaling an application takes on an entirely new meaning, and brings within easy reach visibility into performance characteristics and bottlenecks, and with optimization tools and practices to minimize costs.

More Teeth

In addition to focusing on scaling the demo will highlight these enterprise software features/requirements:

  • polyglot (multiple programming languages, frameworks, libraries, toolsets)
  • message bus centric
  • db heavy: both nosql and sql
  • massive data requirements
  • centralized logging
  • integration complexity, Enterprise Integration Patterns
  • performance techniques / tools / apis
  • multiple interacting layers and components
  • external api (often http-based) to expose entities and behavior CHECK
  • integrated and comprehensive auditing facilities
  • high developer productivity
  • realtime health and performance monitoring

Technology Stack

This POC is be based on a minimalistic application with real-world requirements and technologies including:

  • Java
  • Spring
  • Ruby on Rails and/or Sinatra
  • Camel and Enterprise Integration Patterns
  • html5/javascript/css
  • ActiveMQ Message Bus
  • MongoDB
  • MySQL
  • Loggly

A great starting point is scalability which is one of our most compelling stories and one that generates huge interest at the shows I attend. It also happens to dovetail perfectly with my first “antipatterns” installment.

When I first came across Stackato in July I almost fell out of my chair as its implications hit me. Since that moment I’ve been consumed with its potential and I’ll not rest until I can shed some of these ideas and concepts that are continually tormenting me.

This is mostly centered around Stackato and how it aligns with enterprise software.

Background:

Most Enterprise Software efforts have or require many of these characteristics:

  • multiple interacting layers and components
  • multiple languages, frameworks, libraries, and toolsets
  • clearly defined and measurable scaling strategy
  • strong auditable security with countermeasures across all relevant layers
  • strict auth requirements, elaborate roles, acls, sso
  • centralized logging
  • massive data requirements (tmi)
  • message-based
  • database centric
  • realtime health, performance, and intrusion monitoring
  • integration complexity (EIP)
  • service levels, responsiveness and strict performance and reliability criteria
  • highly available and resilient to major outages
  • external api (often http-based) to expose entities and behavior
  • multiple ports and communications channels
  • notifications and email delivery to user and system
  • extensive services interaction
  • batch and offline operation
  • extensive test capability
  • multiple international language and locales
  • multitenancy
  • integrated and comprehensive auditing facilities
  • mobile aspect
  • portable (what’s this mean?)
  • comprehensable and maintainable codebase and technology stack
  • productive for developers
  • rich web-based UI

In addition to the above, which are development and deployment centric, an entire overlying process must be in place with practices and methodologies the drive the entire development process:

  • development methadology (like scrum)
  • QA
  • test procedures and strategies
  • deployment/release
  • continuous Integration / continuous Delivery
  • configuration management, source code management
  • Monitoring
  • logging
  • hiring / onboarding
  • docs
  • collaboration
  • replication / backups …

This is a huge list (and not comprehensive).

shazzzam!!!! (lightning strike)

Most every bullet point above can be GREATLY facilitated by Stackato. The cost savings for teams and organizations, small and large, can be IMMEASURABLE. (These costs can, however, be lower-bound estimated)

App Store Needs some Teeth

Our current demo set (“hello-”, “currency converter”) is compelling but our app store inventory (with exceptions) doesn’t emphasize the enterprise hardiness and sheer value of what Stackato brings to the table.

We need a demo / deck / webcast that clearly showcases Stackato’s contributions to many of the points above.

A great starting point is scalability which is one of our most compelling stories and one that generates huge interest at the shows I attend. It also happens to dovetail perfectly with my first “antipatterns” installment.

Scaling with Stackato

This 45 minute talk/demo will dive into using Stackato to build highly scalable apps.

An enterprise application suite (simplified but real) will be built up, with requirements from the above list of traits: polyglot, database-centric, message-based, auditable, centralized logging, more.

These apps will be deployed to a (previously configured) cluster, at which time I’ll illustrate some amazingly simple techniques, enabled uniquely by the Stackato ecosystem, that can be used to easily pinpoint bottlenecks.

Once identified, the cluster will be tuned to minimize the bottlenecks.

Scaling Summary

Using simple techniques that are unique to a PaaS environment, Stackato gives early visibility of an application’s scaling characteristics, pinpointing bottlenecks, and immediately scaling out to accomodate if necessary.

Now the rest of the demo

Pick each point from the above list:

  • multiple interacting layers and components
  • multiple languages, frameworks, libraries, and toolsets
  • clearly defined and measurable scaling strategy
  • etc. etc. etc. etc.

And show how Stackato greatly facilitates and aides the requirements/feature/characteristic
